voice_to_text: After we published our Sicilian video, new research came out about another way they feed their babies. Okay, so first of all, that's not. Go watch the rest of that video, but that's not even close to the only weird thing about these guys. So let's get into it. These are Sicilians, which are mostly blind, mostly limbless amphibians, and some of them are ovoviperous, meaning their babies start out in eggs, but the eggs hatch inside of the mom. And while they're in there, the mom makes, like, a fatty, milky liquid to feed them. But according to the 2024 study, at least one species nurses their babies after they're born, which is supposed to be our thing. And by ours, I mean mammals. Anyway, once they're, like, outside of their moms, babies of the species siphonops annulatis will eat their mother's skin for nourishment, which not too weird for Sicilians, but it is, like, weird to me. But the moms in this species also feed their babies a fatty fluid similar to the million milk. And these guys don't have nipples, so the mom, like, secretes this liquid from her cloica, which is the opening that some animals have instead of separate holes for reproduction and digestive waste. So the tiny Sicilians make, like, these high pitched clicks while hovering around that opening, which triggers mom to produce the fluid. And then they just shove their heads in the opening and they drink. And remember, they have teeth. So, yeah, there's just so, so much going on with these weird little guys.

But in these descriptions of reality, time isn't just another dimension. It has a distinct character in a mathematically defined way. See, the way that we talk about space time is with a 4 by 4 array of numbers called the space time metric. Each of these columns or rows corresponds to one of the dimensions. And in particular, the three space dimensions have a positive signs and the time direction has a negative sign. This arrangement of signs is called the signature of the spacetime. Three pluses and one minus And this notion of signature generalizes. We say that positive signs correspond to spatial dimensions and negative signs correspond to temporal dimensions. So for studying the spatial geometry of a piece of paper, the signature is plus, plus. If we're studying the universe of flatlanders, the signatures plus, plus, minus. Importantly, the signature of a geometric space is fixed. It doesn't matter if you're living in that space or if you're viewing it from a higher dimension. You'll always see spatial dimensions of spatial and temporal dimensions as temporal. So for a 4D viewer, our time dimension would still be a time dimension. voice_to_text: so I just saw this video by Georgia in grad school where she's asking if academics like actually steal each other's ideas like is that something that actually happens and especially she's wondering this because like academia seems so collaborative and the whole point is to like build on each other's work and um we're supposed to all be working together right and yeah 1,000,000% it does happen um so she's doing a PhD in the humanities and I am in science so I thought I would talk a little bit about how it works here in science um I don't know if it's the exact same in the humanities but I do imagine it’s something that happens so there's this concept called scooping and it can happen in two ways one is a lot more innocent than the other so research can often take years to publish there's work that I did um like 10 years ago that still has not been published and because it can take so long to publish and also because we're sort of all working off of other people's work it is fairly common that two labs will have the same idea around the same time and just one will publish before the other and so that's one method of scooping someone two labs independently had the same idea and just one publish before the other and that makes it incredibly difficult for the other one to publish and I've seen that happen to many of my friends and colleagues um it's just a rough thing that we have to deal with but no one's really like at fault here and while it does like really suck whenever it happens it's also at least a little bit validating that you were on the right track and you weren't the only one who like thought of it the most famous case of this happening is actually the theory of evolution so um Charles Darwin and a man named Alfred Russell Wallace both came up with the theory of evolution that we like think of today around the same time and people like to frame this as the other method of scooping that I'll talk about um because it's more dramatic but what actually happened is they came up with the idea around the same time they talk to each other realize that they were having the same idea and they actually ended up presenting the theory of evolution together but the first time that it was published it was published by Darwin and that's why we associate Darwin with the theory of evolution instead of Alfred Russell Wallace but in this case they were great friends and colleagues and they didn't like hold it against each other there wasn't like a massive rivalry here it's just something that organically happens sometimes the other method of scooping is you see someone else's research idea and you go actually that's gonna be my idea and then you steal it the way that I've seen this happen most commonly is when you're at conferences a lot of times you're presenting unpublished work and um sometimes people who are big names in the field will come by your poster and be like oh my god this is so interesting my lab does something really similar but not exactly the same as this and then like a year later they'll publish on exactly what you were presenting a fun thing that happened to me one time which is not necessarily scooping but it was incredibly annoying is uh I was constantly suggesting this thing to the faculty member because they were doing something wrong and they were it was it was such an obvious route that they should have gone down that they were like not doing and then whenever they finally did do it they gave me no credit and pretended like this was organically just a thing that they came up with now why do things like scooping and like stealing people's ideas happen whenever like science is supposed to be so collaborative it's because this concept of being so collaborative is actually fairly recent and this is part of why studying like the history of science is really important so way way way way way back in the day science was only for the wealthy elite who could go to school and like fund their own labs and their own research um and also only for like white men at least in Europe there was also research happening in other countries but I don't know as much about it and there were all of these like academic societies that these men could like be a part of that were essentially a bunch of men sitting around smoking and drinking together and talking about their theories that were just like wild ideas and so science like was not for the public and because these were a bunch of men with really big egos it also wasn't really for each other like they wanted to be the name that was attached to this thing so while they were like all talking to each other It it it they were essentially having like these giant 🍆 measuring contest where like yeah they were talking to each other about their science but they were just trying to prove that their science was better than everyone else's and even as science became like more open to other people other people were able to go to college and start joining labs and doing research that attitude of um having your name attached to the research and like it being known as like your research really prevailed even to the modern day there are labs to this day that will on purpose train you incorrectly so that you can't like surpass them like if I were in one of those labs as a PhD student and I was assigned an undergrad I might train that undergrad incorrectly to make sure that that undergrad doesn't get into grad school and then surpass me I would never do that this is a hypothetical but also a very real thing that happens or there are labs that just straight up won't train you because their attitude is that if you can't figure it out on your own then you don't deserve to be here which is wild because none of us like figured out PCR on our own even the people who invented that they were working together and you'll still see labs at like conferences that only present published work and it's incredibly annoying because the whole point of the conference is to share your ideas with each other and get to know like what the up and coming research is like I said stuff that's been published was done like five six 10 years ago so like the point of the conference is to know what's going on right now um so it's really annoying when they do that but also it's to protect their information so that they don't get scooped so yeah the fact that we think of science as like a collaborative environment is really recent like last 30 years recent it's actually really interesting nowadays like sometimes whenever people interview for PhD uh positions they'll like ask how collaborative the environment is like what could they possibly be trained by a different professor if a different professor like knew a technique that they wanted to use for their project um and a lot of older faculty members are really like taken aback by that but that's something that people would care about so yeah um the TLDR is that science while we tend to think of it as collaborative today um it came from very snooty um private origins and of people really wanting to attach their name to a big thing and people with big egos and so um thinking of it as collaborative now is really modern and so there's still this attitude of wanting to be better than everyone else and so yeah people will absolutely steal each other's research

#stitch with @Amburgler Don't store avocados in water! This "hack" puts you at a high risk for getting seriously sick. #science #stem #scienceeducation #foodsafety #microbiology #medlabscience #medicine #kitchensafety #avocadohack #avocados
voice_to_text: ......... I hate to be the bearer of bad news here, but unfortunately TikTok is pretty good at spreading misinformation regarding food safety and this little hack of storing avocados in water is a perfect example of that. If you're new to my page, if you've never seen my videos before, welcome! I'm a microbiologist and a medical laboratory scientist and I'm here stitching this video to pass on some really important food safety information so we can all be better protected from preventable disease like Listeria and Salmonella. This little kitchen hack of storing avocados in water in this way has gained a lot of traction recently thanks to it being shared on social media and people noticing that after they store their avocados fully immersed in water in this way they do stay green for longer. However, the color of the avocado fruit doesn't tell you if it is safe to eat in regards to bacterial contamination, the colour of the fruit will stay the same whether or not it's contaminated by those dangerous bacteria. So where do the bacteria come from? They're already on the avocado. It is very common to find Listeria but also Salmonella on the outside of the avocado, specifically within the root scar (that little indentation at the top of the avocado.) This root scar acts as a reservoir for bacteria, and because of its indentations, because of its irregularities, it can't be cleaned even if you are fully immersing the avocado in for example, a bleach solution. So then when we immerse the avocado in water, that moist environment allows those bacteria to infiltrate the fruit moving from the outside of the root scar into the pulp of the fruit. Like said, we can't tell by looking at the avocado if it's been contaminated we can't tell by a smell or by a taste these pathogens often don't cause spoilage. I know what you're thinking "how do we actually know that happens though?" science my friend! we have scientific evidence from a laboratory where scientists did this method, they immersed avocados in water and they found that these bacteria were able to infiltrate the fruit of the avocado because of the water because of that moist environment. So yes your avocados might not rot, might not spoil as fast, however they are now at a higher risk for bacterial contamination meaning that you are at a higher risk of contracting serious, painful, bacterial disease. I know in our society in our modern day culture we've kind of been conditioned to view food poisoning as no big deal "it's just an upset stomach I'll be fine." we certainly shouldn't lose respect for the harm and the devastation that these organisms can cause. Listeria can lead to meningitis, while Salmonella can cause all kinds of things including arthritis, while repeated bouts of food poisoning in general lead to a higher risk of developing autoimmune disease. If you would like a safe way to store your avocados long term here's what you can do instead. You can peel the fruit of the avocado, chop it up or dice it up, whatever you prefer and then put it in your freezer, this way it can stay fresh and safe to eat for up to three months. Always take the food hacks, the kitchen hacks that you see on TikTok with a very large grain of salt, always double check to make sure the advice you are hearing is safe and that it won't make the food you are feeding yourself or your family dangerous to eat. Thank you for watching this video, thank you for staying to the end and I really really hope you learned something new

voice_to_text: "should I do a candida cleanse or parasite cleanse? here's what you need to know." I can answer that one! NO! ....that was fun  if you've never seen my videos before, welcome! I'm a microbiologist and a medical laboratory scientist  so I am also very invested in protecting you from parasites more specifically the ones that are interested in the contents of your wallet. oops said the quiet part out loud there didn't I? so here's what you actually need to know about these purported "cleanses" that the people marketing them probably aren't telling you. these supplements have never undergone randomized, controlled, clinical trials (which is what we use to test pharmaceutical medication) demonstrating that they work. I know, bare minimum. I don't know about you but me personally before I put any supplement, any medication into my body I need to know that it works first. and here's what you need to know about Candida: Candida is a fungus and it's a normal constituent of the human microbiome it lives in our mouth but it also lives in other parts of our digestive system like the colon. for this reason most people who undergo these screening tests for "Candida overgrowth" will have a positive result. does this mean you have an infection? NO. Candida can be pathogenic, meaning it can cause infections, one example is oral thrush but it can also cause infections on the skin. however "Candida overgrowth" or the idea that systemically Candida can be building up and causing these vague, over-applicable symptoms like hair loss, bloating and depression is quackery 🦆 🦆 this is used to sell supplements to people that they don't actually need. if you have a systemic overgrowth of Candida, if you have a systemic infection with this fungus you are in the hospital in the ICU, fighting for your life not dealing with vague symptoms like hair loss depression and insomnia people who tout these supplements use over-applicable vague, symptoms that anyone can relate to because it makes it more likely for them to get their check 🤑🤑🤑 so what about parasites? there are a huge variety of parasites (notice how these people are never specific that's a red flag)  These parasites can be acquired through food or through unclean drinking water, while others can be acquired by walking barefoot on contaminated soil, and others can be acquired by interacting physically with animal or with human waste. depending on the parasite, depending on how you were exposed and depending on the point of its life cycle it can be in your skin it can be in your lungs or it can be in your digestive system. how do these supplements differentiate between where the parasite is? THEY DON'T!! remember: like I mentioned earlier these supplements have never been demonstrated clinically to work, bare minimum. what these supplements actually do is cause intense gastrointestinal inflammation which can create ✨artifact✨ that is left behind in the toilet, this gives the illusion and the confirmation that something happened and it removed something from my body even when the thing is quite literally the lining of your gastrointestinal system. We even have peer-reviewed scientific literature noting how these supplements are designed this way to cause this clumping to give the illusion that something happened. this is where I once again ask: where's the scientific literature demonstrating that these supplements work? you won't find any! but let me finish with a simple question: there are indeed parts of the world that deal with endemic, parasitic infections (endemic means the parasite is to some level always present within the population) you've probably heard people reference how certain parts of the world undergo yearly (if not more often) parasitic "cleanses" because these parasites are so common. in these parts of the world that deal with these endemic infections they aren't using parasite cleanses from TikTok Shop or various other social media platforms. they are using pharmaceutical medications that have undergone randomized, controlled clinical trials demonstrating that they work. if the areas that are constantly dealing with these gastrointestinal parasites are using pharmaceutical medications and not random supplements why aren't you? if these ✨gut health✨ girlies legitimately want to help people, if they legitimately want to help you address your concerns if you are scared that you have a parasitic infection why don't they instruct you to talk to your doctor about albendazole? why don't they tell you that mebendazole and pyrantel are antiparasitic medications that are available over the counter without a prescription that have been demonstrated clinically to work? it's because they can't make money off of it, so they tell you that you need to take a supplement instead. hey what do I know? I'm just a microbiologist I'm just an MLS that has physically interacted with some of these organisms in a clinical laboratory. I'm positive that the former personal trainer and former gymnastics coach knows so much more. thank you for watching this video thank you for staying to the end and please be cautious and careful before putting random, unregulated untested supplements into your body just because a tiktoker 🤑🤑🤑 told you it's what you need.

voice_to_text: The lights being visible in America wasn't bigger news, but we made such a big deal out of the solar. So I prefer to get answer to this question because I've actually contributed to the problem. And the problem is that the Aurora borealis and Aurora Australia, just so finicky and so hard to forecast that even if you're looking at the Aurora forecast that is released by government agencies, um, up to days in advance, it's usually not accurate until a few hours before the possible displays begin. So you could look up right now and see that four days from now, there is a possibility of Aurora displays taking place. But because of how these events work, like we're talking about coronal mass ejections coming out of the sun that have to interact with the Earth's upper atmosphere in a very particular angle and way in order to generate a rural displays. That is just something that is so hard to predict that usually if it does show that there's a chance of an Aurora, that chance will just drop to zero right before the event begins. Last night, we happened to see the strongest geomagnetic storm in 20 years. And so the Aurora displays were visible in many places around the world that usually do not see this. But it wasn't something that scientists were, like, super confident about until a few hours beforehand. And so there was some media coverage beforehand telling people like, hey, it's Possible. You may be able to see this, but you didn't really see the media coverage crank up until we started seeing the oral displays absolutely going bad shit crazy in Europe, North Africa, India. Just places that are not used to seeing this type of bright, colorful Aurora displays. And so some people were able to see that, but a lot of people were just like, I'm going to bed, and then found out about when they wake up. But with the solar eclipse, that's something we know about, like, hundreds of years in advance. You can look up a map of solar eclipses, exactly where they're going to take place at what time of day in the next 500 years. That's how accessible that information is. So I used to make videos talking about how the Aurora is going to take place in three days. Like, clear your calendar, whatever. voice_to_text: Alright so de-extinction's back in the news I'm gonna talk about it because I've had to do a bit of this during uni um and it's some tech bro bullshit usually. Now I'm not saying that what this guy is doing is bad or anything like that it has a lot of really cool applications and just for context what he's what him and the group he's working with  are kind of trying to do is bring back the thylacine by using their closest relatives which is a small marsupial called a Dunnart, they found in central Australia and using their genetic make up basically to patch in the gaps in the genetic material we have for thylacines in order to create viable embryos we could then potentially implant into a surrogate and then bring the thylacine back, which sounds cool right and it is, it is cool, it's it's a cool thing to do it's just it's nothing like Jurassic Park it is unbelievably more complicated like you need to have both a lot of viable genetic material for your animals case and point we will just realistically will never be able to bring back the dodo because we don't have enough *stuff* (Viable DNA) of dodo around  to create enough of a genetic blueprint to bring them back. Even mammoths are difficult as hell because DNA degrades way faster than people believe, that doesn't necessarily mean you can't sequence a genome if you have enough samples of DNA it just means that you don't have enough to create an actual animal out of it basically but the thing with the extinction is it's it sounds cool it keeps popping up in the news there's a reason 60 Minutes is doing that interview but it's also expensive and time consuming as all goddamn hell like they were talking about how the backers of this program include Leonardo DiCaprio and the CIA like they're doing it with CIA money it's not a small amount of money that's been thrown at this so a lot of conservationists look at this and they have a couple of problems with it first and foremost being why are we spending millions of dollars on the chance to maybe bring back one of the species when we could instead I don't know buy 200,000 acres of Amazon rainforest from being destroyed like there's there's better ways to spend the money than giving a bunch of funky scientists the free rein to maybe bring back I don't know half of a Mammoth. The other thing is little bit less so with the thylacine because they didn't only died out in the 30s um whereas other animals they've *sequenced* options for the extinction include the Mammoth it's like where do you put them Like congratulations we spent $100 million to bring back one thylacine that's not enough to save the species that's not enough to bring back the species they're not the species because they're not thylacines they've got like 40-30% Dunnart DNA instead and all of that money could have been put to I don't know stopping the Great Barrier Reef from disappearing. And the other thing that pisses off a lot of conservationists  about de-extinction is it creates this notion that animals can come back they can't if something's gone it's gone unless we have a Time Machine or this technology suddenly jumps 50 years in front they're gone forever we need to be stopping extinction before it happens and that's not even getting into how if we did bring back one of the animals we've still only got one and you can't create a viable population with that so now your millions of dollars out of pocket so that you can watch an animal go extinct again  this is actually happened before I’ll do a video on that because we brought one species back from extinction it's also the only species to go extinct twice so it didn't work out but that's a whole other video so yeah so yeah it's a it's a cool thing to see pop up on like the news and social media sites when this sort of thing happens but it's not it's not a solution it's something that people can say hey look at this cool thing we're doing if you wanna save animals the easiest way to do it is to talk to people who work with those animals and find out what they need it's it's boring but it's more effective than trying to clone a fuckin Mammoth.

voice_to_text: since it's apparently not nearly as common knowledge as I thought let's go over the carbon cycle and why carbon emissions and pollution are causing climate change to accelerate climate changes natural the world goes through cycles but we are accelerating it faster than the organisms on planet can adapt okay so that's the reason why climate change is a problem at our level now everything that's alive has carbon in it everything that is alive that has carbon and the soil has carbon in it and oil in the ground has carbon in it what we don't want is atmospheric carbon and when you burn carbon materials and you use other chemical processes to alter those carbon materials you create things like carbon monoxide carbon dioxide methane chlorofluorocarbons all of these are atmospheric or gaseous carbon compounds the issue with these compounds is that they allow the sun's energy to come in and not to go out of our atmosphere so the light comes in it heats things and then the heat is not able to escape that is what is increasing the speed of climate change again climate change naturally happens throughout the earth cycle but we are accelerating it much faster by burning carbons that were safely stored in the soil in solid compounds into the atmosphere in gaseous compounds they're called greenhouse gases because they hold in the heat just like a greenhouse except instead of having a nice little house around a few plants it's around the entire world which does cause natural disasters all over the world because weather patterns are changing faster than the various climates can adapt soil is being washed away too quickly cause too much rain is falling in certain areas causing massive massive amounts of flooding and landslides and things like blizzards are happening and heat waves and a bunch of other things that are directly related to carbon emissions caused by are use of fossil fuels and again I never claimed to be a perfect human being none of us can be perfect I don't care who you are none of us can be perfect and believe me if I could make a living without my car I would be happy to do so I did walk for a long time unfortunately I can't afford to live close enough to work to be able to walk if you made it this far in the video thank you for listening and I hope you Learned something um don't give up because there are a lot of people out there making a lot of really really ignorant comments and it's just cause they don't know any better but if we all take a little bit of time to do a little bit of research and understand what we're talking about we would all be better off
